body.p: I received your large and kind letter in due time & was glad to hear that you werwere well & enjoying your self. I was out on pass the day your letter come and when I came in & they gave it me I thought that it was a furlowfurlough, or a discharge or something better yet, a commission as a Colonel or BrigadearBrigadier General, to command Armory Square Hosp—but as it was it pleased me more than any, for I care more for a letter from you than I would for a Com.

Now I suppose that you would like to know how I enjoy my self: Well I go out most every day but I do not get them big dinners that I uesuse to. & I feel quite lost without you hear, but I must be contented to let you remain at home on furlowfurlough for a short time, for when you get back I want you to attend Congress with me, as I am a going up to hear the speaking whenever I can get out—(which is pretypretty often now) I have not bin up to the N. York dining rooms but once since you left so I do not know how things is getting along thearthere.

Things in the Hospital has maid quite a chaingchange. it has binbeen filled up with wounded since you left. in this ward we had three Colonels and one Major & one AdjudantAdjutant General and several other commissioned officers amongst whomewhom werwere two Rebblerebel LieutenentsLieutenants—and three reb privates! but to day the rebs werwere all sent off that werwere able to go, so we have no rebs in this ward, but thearthere is some in some of the other wards!—Two of the Colonels and all of the rest of the commissioned officers that were able to be transferedtransferred: were transferedtransferred to the Hospital at Georgetown, so we aintain't got so many shoulder strapesstraps hear, but we have got enough yet for my use. I think that this last battle has bin a verryvery hard battle, but it has bin a decided victory although it has cost a many a life for thearthere was a great many of our men killed & wounded

The rebs that was in this ward were verryvery saucy. they werwere as confident of gaining their indapendance as we as of whipping them. they say that they have got plenty to eat and wear, (but I thought by the look of them that they had not enough to ware for they werwere verryvery ragged) or maybe they but on thearthere old clothes to fight in. (I forgot to ask em that)

I will commence writing again. My leg is rather worse this morning & the Doctor sayessays that I must stay in bed to day, so I suppose that I must spend the day in bed the best way I can so I will write you another sheatsheet full Well this is saturdaySaturday & they are a scrubbing the floor. so it will be wet hear all forenoon, so I think that I will be as well in bead as any place else, so I must lay and content myself—Now I suppose that you would like to hear something about the boys that werwere home on furlowfurlough. Sargent Denison has got back—H. Benton has not got back yet although his furlowfurlough was out the 10th, several others of the boys has got back that went home to vote—I received a letter from Bush since he went home. he is well and enjoying him self, he sayessays, he sent a great deal of love to you & said that he was a going to write to you, so I expect that thearthere is a letter hear for you now from him (Your letter I did not do quite with it as you told me. that is I did not take it to each one, but I took it to the lady nurse of each ward & told her to read it her self (which she did in public) and then to pass it to each one of the men that werwere mentioned in it, for them to read, and than to let each one read it that wanted to so when that was don I would carry it to the next ward and do the saimsame with it thearthere and so on all through the Hosp. It was in every ward and they all read it that wanted to amongst the rest Dr. Draper read it—they were all verryvery much pleased with it)— All of the old patients are a getting along well—but thearthere is a good many deaths amongst those that werwere brought in last. they are all verryvery badly wounded. and the most of them are wounded in the body or head. thearthere are verryvery few wounded in the legs (but some are) That man in ward A that had the Consumption that layedlaid just above the middle door—is still living, he looks better than he did that night when I seen you up thearthere that man with the bad arm & that man with the bad legeslegs are mending—in fact thaythey are all doing so well as they can—They have just began to build the ChappleChapel & Library that thearthere has bin so much talk about, this morning but if they are as long about getting it finished as they were a getting the floor in this ward it will take them three years or during the war.—then it will not be of much use; will it Well Dear friend I hardly know what else to write to interest you but I will put in something—We still have Miss Lowell hear to run this ward & she is worse than ever since we have got these shoulder straps she does not alowallow me to walk over the floor nor to speak nor nothing else. she eaveneven has a guard to set at each door to keep out the visitors that comes. when a visitor comes he has to send in his card to let Miss Lowell see who it is then sometimes he is admitedadmitted sometimes he is sent away. So you had better set a pack of cards struck off to use when you come back, or maybe Miss Lowell will not be for letting you in. Well I think my letter is getting full long as I must begin to think about closing. I do not expect that you can read one half of it for it is so carelessly wrote and spelt, but what you cannot read you must guess at—that is if you are a yankeyYankee for they are good at guessing—but I must not call you a yankeyYankee you are to honest for to be one The weather is splendid hear verryvery different from what it was this time last year it is verryvery warm we have had but one or two cold disagreeable days.— I expect that they will have the GodressGodess of Liberty summountedmounted on the Capitol as they have maid great progress with it lately. they have got the scaffold all up—I have not bin up to the Capitol for some time, but probilyprobably I will go up on Monday if my leg is better.

Well as I have wrote short enough this time I will close hoping verryvery soon to hear from you—all the boys join me in sending theartheir love to you & your Mother. so good by and may God bless you, from your friend and CompainionCompanion, Lewis K. Brown.
Write soon & oblige LKB. I understood yesterday that ElijaElijah Fox has not gongone home yet, but I did not see him
